maml:description.maml:para: Disables the NAT64 configuration on a computer.
The Disable-NetNatTransitionConfiguration makes the NAT64 configuration ineffective on a computer.
Specifies the network adapter on which to disable the NAT64.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the instance of the NAT64 for which the configuration will be made ineffective.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies to which policy store the NAT64 configuration is applied. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Persistent and Active. If this parameter is not specified, then the cmdlet operates on both active and persistent stores.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the NAT64 configuration object to disable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the network adapter on which to disable the NAT64.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example makes the NAT64 configuration ineffective.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables the NAT64 configuration on a computer.
The Enable-NetNatTransitionConfiguration makes the NAT64 configuration effective on a computer.
Specifies the network adapter on which to enable the NAT64.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example makes the NAT64 configuration effective.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the NAT64 configuration of a computer.

The Get-NetNatTransitionConfiguration cmdlet retrieves the NAT64 configuration of a computer. NAT64 is described in the RFC 6146. NAT64 allows IPv6-only clients to contact IPv4 servers using unicast UDP, TCP, or ICMP.
Specifies the network adapter from which to retrieve the configuration information.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the instance of the NAT64 for which the configuration is being retrieved. If this parameter is not specified, then the configuration for all of the instances of NAT64 are retrieved.

Specifies from which policy store the NAT64 configuration is retrieved. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Persistent and Active. If this parameter is not specified, then the cmdlet operates on both active and persistent stores.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the network adapter from which to retrieve the configuration information.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the instance of the NAT64 for which the configuration is being retrieved. If this parameter is not specified, then the configuration for all of the instances of NAT64 are retrieved.

Specifies from which policy store the NAT64 configuration is retrieved. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Persistent and Active. If this parameter is not specified, then the cmdlet operates on both active and persistent stores.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
The MSFT_NetNatTransitionConfiguration object contains NAT64 configuration information.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example retrieves the NAT64 configuration of a computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new instance of the NAT64 and the associated configuration on a computer.
The New-NetNatTransitionConfiguration creates the NAT64 instance and the associated configuration on a computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Sets the interface on which the NAT64 is listening for the matching incoming IPv6 traffic.

Specifies the list of IPv4 address and port ranges to be used by NAT64 for creating the mappings from IPv6 source address to IPv4 target address. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv4 address,Lowport-Highport>. Such as "10.0.0.2,1024-3388","10.0.0.2,4000-49023". The port value must be between 1024 and 65535. The wildcard character (*) can be specified to use the whole port range, such as 10.0.0.1,*.
Sets the interface on which the NAT64 sends the translated IPv4 traffic.

Specifies to which policy store the NAT64 configuration is applied. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Persistent and Active. If this parameter is not specified, then the cmdlet operates on both active and persistent stores.
Sets the list of IPv6 address ranges to be translated by the NAT64. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv6 prefix,IPv4 subnet>. Such as "69:FF9B::/96,0.0.0.0/0","66:FF9B::/96,192.2.0.0/8".
Sets the enabled state of the NAT64 configuration.

Specifies the lifetime for a TCP mapping after which it is released by the NAT64. The minimum value is 1800 seconds.
The default value is 7200 seconds.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the instance of the NAT64 which is being created.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Sets the interface on which the NAT64 is listening for the matching incoming IPv6 traffic.
Specifies the instance of the NAT64 which is being created.

Specifies the list of IPv4 address and port ranges to be used by NAT64 for creating the mappings from IPv6 source address to IPv4 target address. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv4 address,Lowport-Highport>. Such as "10.0.0.2,1024-3388","10.0.0.2,4000-49023". The port value must be between 1024 and 65535. The wildcard character (*) can be specified to use the whole port range, such as 10.0.0.1,*.
Sets the interface on which the NAT64 sends the translated IPv4 traffic.

Specifies to which policy store the NAT64 configuration is applied. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Persistent and Active. If this parameter is not specified, then the cmdlet operates on both active and persistent stores.
Sets the list of IPv6 address ranges to be translated by the NAT64. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv6 prefix,IPv4 subnet>. Such as "69:FF9B::/96,0.0.0.0/0","66:FF9B::/96,192.2.0.0/8".
Sets the enabled state of the NAT64 configuration.

Specifies the lifetime for a TCP mapping after which it is released by the NAT64. The minimum value is 1800 seconds.
The default value is 7200 seconds.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>$nat64Prefix = "2009:1:2:3:4:5::/96"
PS C:\>$prefixMapping = "$nat64Prefix,0.0.0.0/0"
PS C:\>$portPool = "33.0.0.1,6000-10000"
PS C:\>New-NetNatTransitionConfiguration -InstanceName NAT64 OutboundInterface corpnet -PrefixMapping $prefixMapping -IPv4AddressPortPool $portPool

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a NAT64 configuration for the instance named NAT64.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the NAT64 configuration for one or more instances on a computer.
The Remove-NetNatTransitionConfiguration cmdlet removes the NAT64 configuration for one or more instances on a computer.
Specifies the network adapter on which to remove the NAT64 configuration.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>$nat64Prefix = "2009:1:2:3:4:5::/96"
PS C:\>$prefixMapping = "$nat64Prefix,0.0.0.0/0"
PS C:\>$portPool = "33.0.0.1,6000-10000"
PS C:\>Set-NetNatTransitionConfiguration -InstanceName NAT64 OutboundInterface corpnet -PrefixMapping $prefixMapping -IPv4AddressPortPool $portPool

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the NAT64 configuration for the instance named NAT64.
